issues.title: Missing Compulsory Education Age Update
issues.description: The policy states compulsory education applies to children "between the ages of 6 and 18" but California law was amended in 2012 to extend compulsory education through age 18 or graduation. The current law requires attendance until age 18, not just "between" these ages, and includes specific provisions for students who have completed high school requirements.

legal_citations.text: Each person between the ages of 6 and 18 years not exempted under the provisions of this chapter or Chapter 3 (commencing with Section 48400) is subject to compulsory full-time education.

issues.required_language: Each child between the ages of 6 and 18 years is subject to compulsory full-time education, unless exempted under the provisions of law. Students who complete the graduation requirements for high school before the end of their senior year shall remain enrolled in school or in alternative educational programs until the beginning of the school term following their 18th birthday.

issues.title: Missing Home Schooling Exemption
issues.description: The regulation fails to include home schooling as a valid exemption from attendance, which is a significant omission given that home schooling is explicitly recognized under California law as meeting compulsory education requirements.

legal_citations.text: Children being instructed in study and recitation for at least three hours a day for 175 days each calendar year by persons capable of teaching may be exempted from attendance at the public schools.

issues.required_language: 6. Is being instructed at home by a parent, guardian, or other person having charge or control of the child, provided that the instruction consists of study and recitation for at least three hours a day for 175 days of each calendar year by persons capable of teaching (Education Code 48222)

issues.title: Missing Exemption Process and Criteria
issues.description: Neither the policy nor regulation specifies the process for requesting exemptions, required documentation, approval criteria, or appeal procedures. This creates ambiguity in implementation and potential due process concerns.

legal_citations.text: Pupils subject to compulsory full-time education may be exempted by the governing board of the school district under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the governing board and approved by the county superintendent of schools.

issues.required_language: The Superintendent or designee shall establish procedures for reviewing and approving exemption requests, including required documentation, timelines for decisions, and appeal processes. All exemption decisions must be approved by the county superintendent of schools as required by law.

issues.title: Outdated Private School Affidavit Reference
issues.description: The regulation references Education Code 33190 for private school affidavits, but this section was renumbered. The current requirement is found in Education Code Section 48222.

legal_citations.text: Children attending a private full-time day school shall be exempted from attending the public schools if the private school files an affidavit as specified.

issues.required_language: Is being instructed in a private full-time school and the district attendance supervisor or designee verifies that the private school has filed an affidavit pursuant to Education Code 48222
